--- In junit@y..., ghouston@i... wrote:
> 
> I've used both the seperate directory approach and same directory 
> approach.  Both worked fine, so use which ever you like.
> 
> My preference is to put the test in the same directory as the 
> class.  
> I like this because it reduces the number of clicks I have to make 
> in my IDE (JBuilder) to get from production class to test class.  
> When you are developing in a test-first fashion, you will 
> frequently switch between the test code and the production code.  
> By putting them in the same directory this makes it easier to 
> navigate in the IDE.  Yes, this mixes production and test files 
> together.  However it is very easy to seperate them in a build 
> script (if you use a simple naming convention for test files).  
> Since you will spend more of your work day navigating between 
> source files than seperating out test code, I chose to optimize the 
> # of clicks I had to make in the IDE by putting files in the same 
> directory.

I don't see how putting tests in the same directory optimizes mouse 
clicks.  Doesn't JBuilder allow opening multiple files?  With 
NetBeans, I can just use a tabbed pane or pull out the file into a 
separate window.  The Emacs folks (which there are apparently a lot 
of of around here) can split the window.  

I prefer a separate test directory for purely aesthetic reasons.  I'm 
am more and more inclined to support using the same package to allow 
package/protected access simply because I'd rather risk suboptimal 
designs than inhibit testing.  I don't test private methods directly 
because to me that is too strong a design smell to leave alone. 

> I use the following naming convention:
>   Someclass.java
>   SomeclassT.java // the unit test
>   SomeclassM.java // a mock object of Someclass

It would seem clearer to use SomeClassTest, MockSomeClass.
